results.title: Hang onto yourself: no fun
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Dancing in the street: a rock and roll history”.
In ‘Hang onto yourself’, this episode features an in-depth look at the many faces of David Bowie, particularly as the glam phenomena Ziggy Stardust. The rise of performers such as Alice Cooper, Lou Reed and Ziggy is seen as a response to the hangover from the summer of love where rock developed theatricality. The rise of Reggae and Punk music is the subject of the episode entitled ‘No fun’ and features clips and interviews with pivotal figures such as Malcolm McClaren, The Sex Pistols, Bob Marley and Talking Heads.

results.title: Crossroads. Eight miles high
results.creator_credit: Alan Lewens, Karen Walsh, Mick Conefrey, High Thomson, BBC and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Dancing in the street: a rock and roll history”.
The Blues crosses the Atlantic and reaches Britain where it finds a new direction. Groups like the Beatles and the Rolling Stones invade America and somewhere in the process Heavy Metal is invented. In this episode entitled ‘Crossroads’, interviews and performances by legendary musicians such as The Rolling Stones, Eric Clapton, Jeff Beck are featured. In the second program ‘Eight miles high’ the whole phenomenon of Psychadelia is explored, including interviews and clips from The Grateful Dead, Janis Joplin and Pink Floyd. This episode captures a landmark era in the development of rock music in the 1960’s.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alan Lewens, Karen Walsh, Mick Conefrey, High Thomson, BBC and WGBH (Boston)

results.title: Whole lotta shaking: R.E.S.P.E.C.T.
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Hugh Thompson, BBC and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Dancing in the street: a rock and roll history”.
Whole lotta shakin examines the grass roots beginnings of rock and roll. In New Orleans, Afro-american performers like Little Richard were unleashing a new type of music which echoed through the Mississippi Delta into Sam Phillips’ Studio in Memphis. What was predominantly Afro-american music became “legitimised” commercially when singers like Elvis Presley emulated this energetic form of music. “R.E.S.P.E.C.T”: Motown and Stax records paved the way for legendary Afro-american singers to become successful in their own right. Aretha Franklin was the Queen of Soul, but artists like Ray Charles, Martha Reeves, Otis Redding and the Supremes also made their mark as rock and roll legends.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Espar, Hugh Thompson, BBC and WGBH (Boston)

results.title: Elizabeth R.
results.brief_description: Glenda Jackson received world-wide acclaim for her brilliant portrayal of Queen Elizabeth the Ist. The series begins just prior to Elizabeth’s ascension to the throne and continues to her death in 1603. The episodes deal with historical events such as the Armada, Mary Queen of Scots, the beheading of Essex, the plight over the Succession and her decision to remain unmarried. The series is well scripted, costumed and has an excellent cast.

results.title: The Magic rectangle: short multiplication
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Math that counts”.
Uses rectangular arrays of square metres as a visual model for multiplication and explains the commutative property of multiplication.

results.title: The Great diamond
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Math that counts”.
Repeated division is visualized several times in this humorous animated film. The Drok tribe attempt to smuggle the Great Diamond out of their castle by breaking it into four hundred and eighty-seven pieces. They put sixteen pieces into their boot heels - but how many boots will be needed in all?

results.title: Managing difficult behaviours
results.brief_description: A series of inservice training modules on behaviour management produced by the Developmental Disabilities Staff Development Unit of the University of New England specifically for intellectual disability residential care workers. Each module is accompanied by a training manual.

results.title: Managing disobedient behaviour
results.creator_credit: Tim Abbott, Helen Edwards, Tony Shaddock and New England Educational Diagnostic Centre
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Managing difficult behaviours”.
Module 3.2. Designed to assist the intellectual disability residential care worker to understand what disobedient behaviour is, why it occurs, how to prevent such behaviour, how to deal with disobedience which has become a regular behaviour pattern and how to manage disobedient behaviour crises. Accompanied by 45p. in-service training manual.
